custom-meta.meta-value: 65 Editorial Introduction SAGE Publications, Inc.200910.1177/0265378809103382 DavidBronkema Eastern University's graduate International Development Programs It is a great privilege and blessing to have been asked to guest edit this number of Transformation, in particular because both the Oxford Centre for Mission Studies and Eastern University's MBA in Economic Development program are celebrat- ing their 25th anniversaries this year. It was, in fact, the occasion of this joint anniversary that sparked the articles in this issue. We asked faculty and researchers affiliated with Eastern University's program to identify and analyze current and emerging issues and actors in evan- gelical development efforts that they thought would be important for the future. These authors were selected based on their extensive experience and/or primary research in transformational development. The result, we hope, is a set of articles, in some cases co-written with graduate students of the program, that will spur discussion, reflection, prayer and action by evangelical development academics and practitioners combined. Lindy Backues's article, based on almost two decades of work in Indonesia, kicks off this issue by posing a challenge to the nature and structure of evangelical development organizations and to those who are deeply suspicious of interfaith dialogue. His argument that a `Christian' organizational structure itself can inhibit effective transformational development, and his suggestion and example of an alternative, requires careful consideration. The articles by Bronkema and Brown, Davis, and Ostwald, continue in this vein of casting challenges. They urge Business as Mission and evangelical development practitioners to take seri- ously the political aspects of development, advocacy, and social change, and to take another, and deeper look at understandings of poverty. These three articles also offer insights and guidelines into what this kind of reflection and rethinking might mean in actual practice. The first four articles also point to the importance of the `reawakening' of the evangelical movement to its social responsibilities, a theme that frames the next two articles by Hoiland and Gramby-Sobukwe, and LeQuire and Van Gilder, respectively. Each of these articles identifies a new set of evangelical actors in development (mega-churches and ecotourism non-governmental organizations [NGOs]), and the promises and challenges that await them even as they enrich the conceptualization and practice of transformational development as a whole. Finally, the last article of the issue, by Tom Ridington and Chris Kapp, focuses on 66 a topic that in some ways underpins all the others: insights into the importance of education and training in managing development programs. Ridington and Kapp use an evaluation of Eastern's MBA program as the basis from which to make recommendations in this area. These articles in many ways pay tribute and homage to Transformation's his- tory of tackling the thorny, yet exciting questions of holistic and transformational development. These include human rights (1984, 1[3]); power (1986, 3[4]); 1989, 6[4]); Christian faith and economics (1987, 4[3]; 1990, 7[2]; 2000, 17[2,4]; 2001, 18[3]); charismatic/social activist dialogue (1988, 5[4]); social concerns and evan- gelism (1990, 7[1]); work, employment, and economics (1992, 9[1]), `wholistic' mission (1993, 10[3]); poverty, justice, and the kingdom (1993, 19[11]); Christian relief and development agencies (1996, 13[4]); evidence-based strategies in devel- opment (2002, 19[2]); approaches to reducing poverty (2003, 20[2]); mission and transformational development (2005, 22[2]); and research priorities in develop- ment (2006, 23[3]). We look forward to feedback from and mutual learning with the readers on these and other issues, and invite you to continue this conversation at a major conference on Transformational Development that Eastern University will be co- hosting with Food for the Hungry at St Davids, Pennsylvania, USA, August 7-9 2009.
